headline.main: MINORITY GROUP CHOICES PIVOTAL IN SOME CONTESTS

results.snippet: With white voters divided over which party can better handle the recession, the votes of members of minority groups could decide the outcome of many important races across the nation.   This state, for example, elected an all-Republican...

byline.original: By JOHN HERBERS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: With white voters divided over which party can better handle the recession, the votes of members of minority groups could decide the outcome of many important races across the nation. This state, for example, elected an all-Republican Congressional delegation in 1980, and the party had reason to believe it could make inroads this year into state government, long dominated by Democrats. Instead, the Democrats now are within reach of placing a liberal in a new Congressional seat, of unseating Senator Harrison Schmitt, the former astronaut, and of winning the Governor's office with a flamboyant Hispanic candidate who is considerably to the left of the retiring Governor, Bruce King, a Democrat. Whether the Democrats succeed is expected to depend to a large extent on the turnout of Hispanic voters, even though this vote has been diluted by affluent whites arriving in recent years from other states.

headline.main: SCHMITT LOSES NEW MEXICO SENATE SEAT

results.snippet: In one of the biggest upsets of the 1982 election, Harrison H. Schmitt, the Republican Senator who first gained fame 10 years ago as an astronaut who walked on the moon, was defeated today by his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Jeff Bingaman....

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In one of the biggest upsets of the 1982 election, Harrison H. Schmitt, the Republican Senator who first gained fame 10 years ago as an astronaut who walked on the moon, was defeated today by his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Jeff Bingaman. The loss by the 47-year-old Mr. Schmitt was widely interpreted here as a verdict on both the Reagan economic and environmental programs, which he backed strongly, and on the Senator's negative campaign against his 39-year-old opponent. With 76 percent of the state's 1,231 precincts reporting, the laconic, reserved Mr. Bingaman had 167,651 votes, or 52 percent, to Mr. Schmitt's 154,021 votes. The turnout was extraordinarily heavy, about 70 percent, state elections officials said. Early reports said that voting was exceptionally high in the normally Democratic precincts in Albuquerque and the northern part of the state.

results.snippet: All Congressional and gubernatorial incumbents in the five-state Rocky Mountain region were returned to office Tuesday. The voters seemed more comfortable with preserving the status quo than with change.   At the same time, Republicans scored gains...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: All Congressional and gubernatorial incumbents in the five-state Rocky Mountain region were returned to office Tuesday. The voters seemed more comfortable with preserving the status quo than with change. At the same time, Republicans scored gains in contests for two new House districts in Colorado and Utah. Jack Swigert, a former astronaut, won handily in Colorado's new Sixth District southwest of Denver. In Utah, Howard C. Nielson, a professor at Brigham Young University, crushed his Democratic opponent with 77 percent of the vote in the state's Third District.

headline.kicker: VICTORIES BRING AN INCREASE IN NATIONAL PROMINENCE TO SEVERAL POLITICIANS

results.snippet: Newly elected Governor of Wisconsin ... 46-year-old Democrat ...  former member of the State Legislature ... a liberal with strong support from groups of political activists ... campaigned for a nuclear arms freeze ... served as Secretary of...
results.lead_paragraph: Newly elected Governor of Wisconsin ... 46-year-old Democrat ... former member of the State Legislature ... a liberal with strong support from groups of political activists ... campaigned for a nuclear arms freeze ... served as Secretary of Administration and later as Secretary of Natural Resources under Gov. Patrick J. Lucey in the 1970's ... won gubernatorial nomination this year by defeating Martin J. Schreiber, the one-time acting governor. Richard H. Bryan Governor-elect of Nevada ... 45-year-old liberal Democrat ... state attorney general ... barely won half the vote in the Democratic primary to defeat Lieut. Gov. Myron E. Leavitt, a conservative ... succeeded in attracting enough conservative support to thwart reelection bid of Gov. Robert F. List, a Republican ... their campaigns centered largely on proposals and counterproposals on best ways of raising tax revenues. William Sheffield Governor-elect of Alaska ... 54-year-old Democrat ... a millionaire who owns a chain of 10 hotels in Alaska and the Yukon Territory ... broke all state records by spending more than $1 million, much of it his own money, to win nomination ... campaigned in remote ''bush'' country, picking up support in small villages usually ignored by politicians ... opposed proposal of Republican opponent, Tom Fink, to move state capital from Anchorage to Willow, 70 miles away.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE SET FOR CRITICAL CHANGE FROM TESTS TO REAL WORK

results.snippet: The nation's space shuttle Columbia is ready to make the critical transition from flight testing to the hauling of orbital freight, the culmination of a decade-long, $11 billion project.   The fifth launching of the shuttle, scheduled for 7:19 A.M....

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The nation's space shuttle Columbia is ready to make the critical transition from flight testing to the hauling of orbital freight, the culmination of a decade-long, $11 billion project. The fifth launching of the shuttle, scheduled for 7:19 A.M. today, will set the stage for the first deployment of satellites from the shuttle's huge cargo bay, a method of placing craft in an orbit of the earth that will eventually make expendable rockets obsolete. The Columbia is carrying two communications satellites for the project's first two paying customers, Satellite Business Systems Inc. and Telesat Canada. The planned five-day mission will also feature the largest astronaut crew, two pilots and two mission specialists, and the first ''space walk'' by Americans since 1974. The three and a half hour extravehicular activity, as it is known formally, is set for Sunday morning.

headline.main: SKETCHES OF THE ASTRONAUTS ORBITING EARTH TODAY ABOARD THE SPACE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: Vance D. Brand   In the final moments of his last trip into space, Vance Devoe Brand, commander of the current flight of Columbia, was made unconscious for almost a minute by noxious nitrogen tetroxide fumes that were sucked into the cabin. The...
results.lead_paragraph: Vance D. Brand In the final moments of his last trip into space, Vance Devoe Brand, commander of the current flight of Columbia, was made unconscious for almost a minute by noxious nitrogen tetroxide fumes that were sucked into the cabin. The incident occurred on the descent from an otherwise flawless nine-day mission in 1975 in which an Apollo spacecraft made a successful rendezvous with a Soviet Soyuz. Mr. Brand and the other two Apollo astronauts, Maj. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford of the Air Force and Donald K. Slayton, were hospitalized for three days. The descent was unusually noisy with much radio static and excessive sound from the jet thrusters and the rush of air around the capsule. At 30,000 feet, in the midst of all this, Mr. Brand failed to hit two switches. One would have turned off the thrusters that controlled the spacecraft's attitude in space, which were unnecessary in the atmosphere. It was gas from the thrusters that entered the cabin. The other switch was to activate the automatic system that deployed the spacecraft's parachutes.

headline.main: PIECES OF SKYLAB GOING ON SALE

results.snippet: Charles (Pete) Conrad, the astronaut who was commander of the first Skylab mission, said today that pieces of the crashed space vehicle would be sold as souvenirs, with the revenues to go to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.  ...
results.lead_paragraph: Charles (Pete) Conrad, the astronaut who was commander of the first Skylab mission, said today that pieces of the crashed space vehicle would be sold as souvenirs, with the revenues to go to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Skylab was a manned satellite laboratory that circled the earth from 1973 until 1979, when it fell out of orbit. The inch-square pieces of the satellite that are being sold are fitted into colorful posters and cost $20 each, plus $2 for shipping. Proceeds will go to support work connected with analyzing data being received from Viking 1, which is transmitting from Mars.

headline.main: SHUTTLE LIFTS OFF IN FIFTH MISSION WITH CREW OF 4

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia returned to orbit today, and in its inaugural mission as a space freighter, successfully released the first of two satellites it was hauling for the program's initial paying customers.   Four astronauts, the largest crew...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia returned to orbit today, and in its inaugural mission as a space freighter, successfully released the first of two satellites it was hauling for the program's initial paying customers. Four astronauts, the largest crew ever, rode the winged spacecraft into an 184-mile-high orbit. On their sixth revolution of the earth, they ejected a 7,200-pound business communications satellite from the rear of the open cargo bay. The satellite drifted away, fired its own rocket and then climbed toward a higher orbit.

headline.main: SHUTTLE COMPLETES MAIN TASK BY LAUNCHING ITS 2D SATELLITE

results.snippet: The space shuttle astronauts launched a second communications satellite from the Columbia's bay today, completing their primary objective.   The satellite, Canada's Anik C-3, sprang free of the shuttle as the astronauts coasted over the Pacific...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle astronauts launched a second communications satellite from the Columbia's bay today, completing their primary objective. The satellite, Canada's Anik C-3, sprang free of the shuttle as the astronauts coasted over the Pacific Ocean on their 22d orbit. Spinning for the sake of stability and cloaked in a multitude of dark blue solar cells, the cylindrical satellite drifted miles away before its rocket fired to raise it toward a higher orbit over the Equator. Dr. Joseph P. Allen, who supervised the operation, reported its success in a voice rising with excitement.

headline.main: SHUTTLE MISSION PUTS FOCUS ON RESEARCH CREWMEN

results.snippet: The fifth flight of the space shuttle Columbia marks a turning point in the space program. For the first time since an American astronaut was lofted into space 21 years ago, the spotlight is off the daredevil pilots who have long been the heroes of...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The fifth flight of the space shuttle Columbia marks a turning point in the space program. For the first time since an American astronaut was lofted into space 21 years ago, the spotlight is off the daredevil pilots who have long been the heroes of space travel. The focus is now on a new breed of space traveler, the mission specialists, the passengers, as it were, who are carrying out the work for which the shuttle was designed. The first two such specialists, Joseph P. Allen, a 45-year-old physicist, and William B. Lenoir, a 43-year-old electrical engineer, are directing all ''onorbit'' activities - carrying out the practical chores, now that the craft has been placed in orbit by the pilots.

results.snippet: A bout of motion sickness, one of the persistent problems of space flight, forced a one-day postponement of plans for two astronauts to take a walk outside the space shuttle Columbia. The space walk was rescheduled for Monday morning.   The...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A bout of motion sickness, one of the persistent problems of space flight, forced a one-day postponement of plans for two astronauts to take a walk outside the space shuttle Columbia. The space walk was rescheduled for Monday morning. The announcement was made late today after flight surgeons decided that Dr. William B. Lenoir, one of the mission specialists, might not be well enough to face the rigors of the three-and-a-half hour Extravehicular Activity, or EVA. He and Dr. Joseph P. Allen were to have worked out in the open cargo bay Sunday morning.

results.snippet: Next to a launching or a moon walk, a space walk ranks as the spectacle of space flight most freighted with risk and suspense. From the security of his spaceship, the astronaut steps into an environment against which he has no natural defense. He...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Next to a launching or a moon walk, a space walk ranks as the spectacle of space flight most freighted with risk and suspense. From the security of his spaceship, the astronaut steps into an environment against which he has no natural defense. He has only the thin garment and backpack that surround him with the essence of Earth, oxygen and cooling water. The danger only heightens the beauty of the moment. The astronaut is a human satellite, an orbiting body. He may hang onto a tether, linking him to the spaceship, but there are many airless miles between him and Earth, and an infinity beyond.

headline.main: SPACE WALK IS SET FOR TODAY

results.snippet: After a fairly relaxed day in orbit today, the Columbia's astronauts were reported to be ready for a space walk outside the shuttle Monday morning, an excursion delayed because one of the mission specialists had motion sickness.   Project officials...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: After a fairly relaxed day in orbit today, the Columbia's astronauts were reported to be ready for a space walk outside the shuttle Monday morning, an excursion delayed because one of the mission specialists had motion sickness. Project officials said the specialist, Dr. William B. Lenoir, had recovered from the nausea he suffered Saturday and the other three crew members were also ''doing exceptionally well.'' Dr. Lenoir and Dr. Joseph P. Allen, the other specialist aboard the Columbia, are scheduled to step through an airlock into the vacuum of space at 7:50 A.M. Monday. Dressed in new, more flexible pressure suits, the two men are to spend three and a half hours in the shuttle's open cargo bay, evaluating the suits and practicing their ability to perform spacecraft repairs.

results.snippet: Dr. Joseph P. Allen, a physicist and astronaut, said today that an experiment designed by an 18-year-old student was telling scientists more about the behavior of fluids in space ''than maybe we wanted to know.''   ''It's really most peculiar...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Joseph P. Allen, a physicist and astronaut, said today that an experiment designed by an 18-year-old student was telling scientists more about the behavior of fluids in space ''than maybe we wanted to know.'' ''It's really most peculiar behavior,'' Dr. Allen said from the space shuttle Columbia after describing the strange patterns that vegetable oil took when injected into small heated pans with glass covers. The experiment was developed by Scott Thomas of Johnstown, Pa., a freshman at Utah State University, as part of a program operated by the space agency and the National Association of Science Teachers. The aim is to give young people the use of the weightless environment for scientific tests.

results.snippet: The space suits that malfunctioned yesterday, causing the cancellation of a space walk from the Columbia, are perhaps the most complex human garments ever made. Each one has all the support systems of a one-man spacecraft.   Forty-three suits and...
results.lead_paragraph: The space suits that malfunctioned yesterday, causing the cancellation of a space walk from the Columbia, are perhaps the most complex human garments ever made. Each one has all the support systems of a one-man spacecraft. Forty-three suits and 13 associated back packs have been produced for space shuttle missions at a cost of about $2 million each. They have been tested 70 times under manned conditions and 160 times while unmanned, according to a spokesman for their manufacturer, the Hamilton Standard Division of United Technologies Corporation in Windsor Locks, Conn.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS' WALK CANCELED AS SPACESUITS FAIL

results.snippet: The fifth mission of the space shuttle Columbia had a disappointing failure today when the astronauts' spacesuits malfunctioned, forcing cancellation of what would have been the first walk in space by Americans in almost nine years.   But, with the...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The fifth mission of the space shuttle Columbia had a disappointing failure today when the astronauts' spacesuits malfunctioned, forcing cancellation of what would have been the first walk in space by Americans in almost nine years. But, with the shuttle's most important tasks already behind it and satisfied that the mission was successful, flight controllers told the astronauts to head home as scheduled. They also decided against extending the mission an extra day for another attempt at the space walk because prospects for repair of the suits seemed dim. Landing in Desert The space shuttle was scheduled to end its five-day flight Tuesday morning with a landing on a concrete runway at Edwards Air Force Base in California's Mojave Desert. Favorable weather was forecast for the landing at 9:34 A.M., New York time.

results.snippet: An Egoistic Diktat In Fortuity   Shortly before he died, Leonid Brezhnev assembled his nation's military leaders to read them the riot act for producing the sort of equipment that was clobbered by the Israelis in Lebanon. (The Riot Act was passed...
results.lead_paragraph: An Egoistic Diktat In Fortuity Shortly before he died, Leonid Brezhnev assembled his nation's military leaders to read them the riot act for producing the sort of equipment that was clobbered by the Israelis in Lebanon. (The Riot Act was passed in England in 1715 to enable mayors to issue pronouncements banning the assembly of 12 or more persons; it exists now in vestigial form only as something that is ''read,'' meaning ''the administration of a bawling-out.'' But I digress.) The text of his speech was distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency, and its translation contained three interesting words. First, the speech denounced ''attempts to impose American diktat ... .'' A spokesman for Tass in Washington, asked about that word, replied: ''Diktat is a Russian word for an order or decree, and appears in both the original Russian text and the translation unchanged.''
